raw_text:
Show over for MTV's The Osbournes
 
 Rock star Ozzy Osbourne has said his family will not make any more episodes of reality TV show The Osbournes.
 
 "At the end of it I didn't like having cameras around the house all the time," the Black Sabbath singer told reporters at the MTV Europe Awards in Rome. His wife Sharon, who also appears in the popular MTV show based on the Osbournes' family life, agreed. "Now everybody's doing reality shows. He's done it, he's been there, he's got to do something else," she said.
 
 Ozzy Osbourne said he had had enough of the work involved in making the series. "When you watch a 25-minute episode, I've been filming all day," he said. Sharon Osbourne is currently appearing as a judge and mentor in ITV1 talent show The X-Factor alongside Simon Cowell and Louis Walsh.
 
 Earlier this year she topped a poll of the most important people in rock, for her part in guiding the career of husband Ozzy and her family. She was the driving force behind The Osbournes, which ran for three series, earning the family a reported $85m (£46m). The renewed popularity for Ozzy has seen sales of his merchandise hit the $50m (£27.2m) mark, a record for a heavy metal artist. Sales of T-shirts, accessories and action figures have rocketed since The Osbournes hit screens. At its peak, The Osbournes had a regular audience of eight million, with America's TV Guide magazine describing the series as "a cross between The Simpsons and This Is Spinal Tap". Osbourne himself was at a loss to explain its popularity: "I suppose Americans get a kick out of watching a crazy Brit family like us make complete fools of ourselves every week."
llama3.2:1b: Ozzy Osbourne has said he will not continue the reality TV show The Osbournes. Sharon Osbourne, who also appears on the show, agreed with him. Ozzy had enough of filming and feels pressured to create more content. He is currently focusing on his career after appearing as a judge and mentor on ITV1's talent show The X-Factor alongside Simon Cowell and Louis Walsh.
llama3.2:3b: Ozzy and Sharon Osbourne say they won't do more episodes of The Osbournes, citing cameras being around the house all the time. Ozzy had enough work involved in making the series. Sharon is currently appearing on ITV1's The X-Factor.
gemma2:2b: Ozzy Osbourne has ended filming for *The Osbournes* reality show, citing fatigue.  His wife Sharon Osbourne will continue in other projects and the series' popularity has led to significant earnings for both of them.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Ozzy Osbourne has left MTV’s The Osbournes due to the series' content, having made up his mind to continue with his career outside reality TV. He agreed with Sharon Osbourne's suggestion that he be a judge and mentor on ITV1's The X-Factor alongside Simon Cowell and Louis Walsh.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Ozzy Osbourne's reality TV show The Osbournes is ending, due in part to his growing interest in music. His wife Sharon has also left the show, becoming a judge on ITV1 talent show The X-Factor alongside Simon Cowell and Louis Walsh. Despite being called "a cross between The Simpsons and This Is Spinal Tap", sales of Ozzy's merchandise have increased significantly since its launch, with Osbourne admitting that Americans might enjoy watching him and his family "make complete fools of ourselves" on the show.
qwen2.5:3b: Rock star Ozzy Osbourne has announced that his family will not produce any more episodes of The Osbournes, a reality TV show featuring their family life. Both Ozzy and wife Sharon Osbourne expressed their dissatisfaction with the work involved in making the series. They believe reality TV is becoming overused and suggest it's time for other celebrities to move on from such shows. The Osbournes were popular, earning the family $85 million (£46 million) through three series, and also helped boost Ozzy Osbourne's merchandise sales to a record of $50 million (£27.2 million). Despite its initial popularity, Sharon Osbourne was voted as the most important person in rock for her role in guiding her husband and family.

smollm:1.7b: The summary is concise, preserving the key ideas and details from the original text. It captures the main points without providing any additional explanations or analysis. The summary focuses on the essential information about Ozzy Osbourne's decision to stop making episodes for MTV's reality TV show The Osbournes, highlighting his reasons for doing so and the impact it had on his career.

Ozzy admitted he had enough of reality TV work, stating that a 25-minute episode required filming all day without cameras. Sharon describes herself as a driving force behind the show, which has sold $50m in merchandise, describing it as a mix of "This Is Spinal Tap" and "Simpsons." Ozzy is confused about its popularity but believes Americans get excited by British families' reality shows.
tinyllama:1.1b: Rock star Ozzy Osbourne has revealed that he and his wife Sharon have decided against making any more episodes of MTV's reality TV show The Osbourne. The couple had been filming a third series for six months, but after the recent renewed popularity for Ozzy, they decided to take a break from the project. Earlier this year, the Osbournes topped a poll of the most important people in rock music, while also earning an estimated $85m (£46m) in sales for their merchandise. While it remains unclear why Ozzy and Sharon decided against making any more episodes of The Osbourne, they have expressed gratitude for the success the show has enjoyed since its debut on MTV in 2011.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The Osbournes, MTV's hit reality show based on the lives of the Black Sabbath frontman Ozzy and his family, has come to an end after its third season. In a recent interview with reporters at the MTV Europe Awards in Rome, Sharon Osbourne, Ozzy's wife, revealed that they had decided not to make any more episodes of the show. "At the end of it I didn't like having cameras around the house all the time," she said. The popular reality series featured Ozzy Osbourne, his wife Sharon, and their four children—Tila Tequila, Jessica Simpson, Rachel Uchikawa, and Jack Osbourne—as they navigated the challenges of balancing their careers with family life.
